articles.headline: For Gawker, Legal Issues Beyond Hogan
articles.snippet: Many who have sued Gawker said it overstepped the boundaries of privacy, slandered reputations or failed to do adequate reporting before posting articles.
articles.abstract: Many who have sued Gawker said it overstepped the boundaries of privacy, slandered reputations or failed to do adequate reporting before posting articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gawker Media’s legal battle with Hulk Hogan over the publication of a sex tape has had wide-ranging impact.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: MetLife Suit Raises Questions of Extent of Corporate Liability
articles.snippet: Victims of a Ponzi scheme have sued MetLife, claiming it failed to oversee brokers selling products connected to the insurance giant.
articles.abstract: Victims of a Ponzi scheme have sued MetLife, claiming it failed to oversee brokers selling products connected to the insurance giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Christine Ramirez signed over that first check in April 2008, she had no idea that the decision would eventually upend her life.

articles.headline: President Obama’s Overtime Pay Plan Threatens the ‘Prada’ Economy
articles.snippet: A federal rule on overtime pay endangers a practice in fields like publishing and movies, where low wages are accepted for a kind of apprenticeship.
articles.abstract: A federal rule on overtime pay endangers a practice in fields like publishing and movies, where low wages are accepted for a kind of apprenticeship.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, bosses at publishing houses, glossy magazines, consulting firms, advocacy groups, movie production companies and talent agencies have groomed their assistants to be the next generation of big shots by working them long hours for low wages.

articles.headline: Television Networks Struggle to Provide Equal Airtime in the Era of Trump
articles.snippet: News organizations wonder how to avoid a lopsided view of the election race as Donald J. Trump seems to relish airtime, while Hillary Clinton does not.
articles.abstract: News organizations wonder how to avoid a lopsided view of the election race as Donald J. Trump seems to relish airtime, while Hillary Clinton does not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump relishes the spotlight of live television. Hillary Clinton has long recoiled from it. Now, the television news industry is wrestling with how to balance fairness, credibility and the temptations of sky-high ratings as it prepares for a presidential matchup like none other.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Soured on a Deal, and Hong Kong Partners Became Litigants
articles.snippet: “I beat China all the time,” Mr. Trump said last year, citing one Manhattan investment. But documents and interviews tell a very different story of that deal.
articles.abstract: “I beat China all the time,” Mr. Trump said last year, citing one Manhattan investment. But documents and interviews tell a very different story of that deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who has made reversing America’s trade imbalance a pillar of his campaign, often portrays himself as uniquely capable of wringing concessions out of China through hard-nosed business tactics he has honed over the years.
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: U.S. Struggles With Goal of Admitting 10,000 Syrians
articles.snippet: With the administration struggling to resettle Syrians and preparing to deport more Central Americans, allies and advocacy groups say the president’s actions do not match his words.
articles.abstract: With the administration struggling to resettle Syrians and preparing to deport more Central Americans, allies and advocacy groups say the president’s actions do not match his words.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama invited a Syrian refugee to this year’s State of the Union address, and he has spoken passionately about embracing refugees as a core American value.

articles.headline: Retailers Like H&M and Walmart Fall Short of Pledges to Overseas Workers
articles.snippet: Three years after a factory collapse prompted top brands to commit to bettering worker conditions in Bangladesh, rights groups say problems persist.
articles.abstract: Three years after a factory collapse prompted top brands to commit to bettering worker conditions in Bangladesh, rights groups say problems persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than 1,100 deaths exposed dangerous labor conditions in Bangladesh in 2013, brands like H&M, Walmart and Gap were among the most powerful companies that pledged to improve the safety of some of the country’s poorest workers.

articles.headline: Old and on the Street: The Graying of America’s Homeless
articles.snippet: The emergence of an older homeless population is creating daunting challenges for social service agencies and governments already struggling to fight poverty.
articles.abstract: The emergence of an older homeless population is creating daunting challenges for social service agencies and governments already struggling to fight poverty.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They lean unsteadily on canes and walkers, or roll along the sidewalks of Skid Row here in beat-up wheelchairs, past soiled sleeping bags, swaying tents and piles of garbage. They wander the streets in tattered winter coats, even in the warmth of spring. They worry about the illnesses of age and how they will approach death without the help of children who long ago drifted from their lives.

articles.headline: A Universal Basic Income Is a Poor Tool to Fight Poverty
articles.snippet: In this world where work remains an important social, psychological and economic anchor, there are better tools to help than giving every American a monthly check.
articles.abstract: In this world where work remains an important social, psychological and economic anchor, there are better tools to help than giving every American a monthly check.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why doesn’t the government just give everybody money?

articles.headline: Volkswagen Reports Profit Drop as It Grapples With Emissions Scandal
articles.snippet: The results come as the German carmaker takes steps to recover from its diesel emissions scandal, while pushing through an overhaul across its 12-brand group.
articles.abstract: The results come as the German carmaker takes steps to recover from its diesel emissions scandal, while pushing through an overhaul across its 12-brand group.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Volkswagen is still managing to make money despite an emissions scandal. It is just not making money selling Volkswagens.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Lashes Out at Media While Detailing Gifts to Veterans
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump angrily listed veterans’ groups that he said had received $5.6 million in gifts and demanded that journalists credit his act of charity.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump angrily listed veterans’ groups that he said had received $5.6 million in gifts and demanded that journalists credit his act of charity.
articles.lead_paragraph: He called a news conference ostensibly to answer questions about his fund-raising for charities that benefit military veterans. But Donald J. Trump instead spent most of his time on live television Tuesday berating the journalists covering his presidential campaign in unusually vitriolic and personal terms.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Ashley Parker
